page.title: 09The Marsh and Brickcroft(1)
page.content: One of the main physical features of our area is the marshland that separates Longton from Hesketh Bank. The land is low-lying vegetated saltmarsh and is chiefly used as rough grazing for sheep. It is bisected by the River Douglas and is liable to flooding. In the past the river was well-used. There has always been an inn on the edge of the marsh and it is said that that there was and still is tunnel leading from the Dolphin Inn (known sometimes as the Flying Fish) to the river. Smuggling of Dutch lace and gin was rife at this time.(Early 18th century) Over the years a considerable amount of the marshland was drained and some agriculture developed. Longton Brickcroft was opened in the mid-19th century.The family who owned the land were the Bentleys.(Contd.)
